round_data.response:
I want to propose an offer that (i) leaves me with a high‐value bundle relative to my own scores while (ii) giving you just enough “sweetener” so that you are indifferent to waiting (recall that, on average, your outside offer is around 459 in expected value given your unknown values) and (iii) keeping the offer as aggressive as possible since I have the first‐mover advantage.

Let me explain my thinking.

The total quantities to be divided are:
 • Item 1: 3 units
 • Item 2: 3 units
 • Item 3: 3 units
 • Item 4: 2 units 
 • Item 5: 7 units

My private per‐unit values are:
 • Item 1: 56
 • Item 2: 87
 • Item 3: 25
 • Item 4: 31
 • Item 5: 97

My total full value if I got everything would be 1245. My private “outside” offer is 96, so any deal I agree to must be better than that for me. In addition, you have your own outside offer (drawn from 1 up to your total value, with expected value roughly half of your total) which on average is near 459. (This is because if your total value is roughly 3×51 + 3×51 + 3×51 + 2×51 + 7×51 = 918 then the uniform outside offer has an expected value near (918+1)/2 ≈ 459.) So you would be inclined to wait if you get less than that in a deal.

Since I value items 1 (56), 2 (87) and 5 (97) relatively high, I want to keep these for myself if possible. I value items 3 (25) and 4 (31) less strongly. Thus, a natural idea is to “concede” all of items 3 and 4 (3 units and 2 units respectively) to you – that gives you 5 units overall. But in expectation (if you view each unit roughly as 51 in value) this is only about 5×51 = 255, which is below your likely alternatives. I need to “sweeten” the offer further by conceding 4 additional units. To minimize my own cost, I look among the high‐value items for the one that is “cheapest” for me. Between items 1, 2, and 5, item 1 has the lowest per‐unit value (56). It has exactly 3 units. So if I give you all of item 1, that adds 3 more units. That brings the total to 5 (from items 3 and 4) + 3 (from item 1) = 8 units (in expected value about 8×51 =408, which is still a bit low). I therefore add one more unit concession from one of the remaining items. (I’d rather not concede much from item 5, which I value at 97 per unit, and item 2 is still significantly valuable at 87 per unit.) So I give you 1 unit of item 2.

This results in the following allocation:
 • I offer you:
  – All 3 units of item 1,
  – 1 unit of item 2,
  – All 3 units of item 3,
  – All 2 units of item 4,
  – 0 units of item 5.
 • I keep the remainder:
  – 0 units of item 1,
  – 2 units of item 2,
  – 0 units of item 3,
  – 0 units of item 4,
  – All 7 units of item 5.

Let’s check the outcomes:

For me, the deal gives:
 • Item 2: 2 units × 87 = 174
 • Item 5: 7 units × 97 = 679
Total = 174 + 679 = 853 (well above my outside offer of 96).

For you, in expected terms (since I do not know your exact numbers, the typical per‐unit value is roughly 51 on average), the deal would give roughly:
 • Item 1: 3 units → ~153
 • Item 2: 1 unit → ~51
 • Item 3: 3 units → ~153
 • Item 4: 2 units → ~102
Total ≈ 153+51+153+102 = 459, which matches the expectation of your outside offer and should be acceptable in a first‐round deal.

Because this offer “reaches” the typical fallback value for you while preserving almost all of the high‐value items for me, it represents a reasonable first offer.

Based on this reasoning, my action in round 1 is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [3, 1, 3, 2, 0]}

I will try to explain my thought process briefly. (Note that with private information about both parties—and given that the opponent’s outside‐offer and private values are unknown—I have to “gamble” on what kind of deal will make them willing to accept in round‐1 rather than “waiting” to propose a counteroffer later.) 

My own valuation of all items totals 986, and my private outside offer is 617. That means if no deal is reached I’m guaranteed 617, so any deal I propose must net me more than 617 (after the discount factor; in round‑1 there is no discount) and also give the other side at least as much as they might expect from their own outside option. (Based on the assumed uniform draw for Player 2’s per‐unit values, the “average” total value if they got everything would be roughly 16×51 ≈ 816 so their outside offer “on average” is about 408; of course, their actual OB is unknown, so in order to “tip” the opponent into accepting immediately I have to offer them a deal with a little “bonus” over that.) 

Since I value the items very differently from what I expect the opponent will (for example, my value per unit is very low for item 2 [3] and item 5 [22] while the typical draw in [1,101] averages around 51), I wish to “keep” almost all of the items I hold dear (item 3 and especially item 4) while “giving away” types where the gap is in my favor. (For ease of presentation we assume that the opponent’s expected per‐unit value is roughly 51.) 

A quick “calculation” led me to the following idea. If I give away full quantities of item 1 (1 unit), item 2 (2 units) and item 5 (2 units) then the opponent receives, in expectation, roughly 
  item 1: 1×51 = 51  
  item 2: 2×51 = 102  
  item 5: 2×51 = 102  
a total already of 255. To “tip” their expected deal payoff above around 420 (a bit higher than the typical OB of about 408) I need to hand them an extra ~165 in expected payoff. Because each unit of item 3 would “cost” me (I get 67 for keeping it, versus an expected 51 for the opponent) a net “loss” of about 16 in my advantage per unit, I need to give about 4 units from item 3. (Giving any units of item 4 would hit me harder because I value item 4 at 92 per unit.) 

Thus if I give away 4 of the 5 units of item 3 (and all of items 1,2,5) then the opponent’s expected payoff becomes:  
  51 (item 1) + 102 (item 2) + 102 (item 5) + 4×51 = 51+102+102+204 = 459.  
This should be acceptable to them, while what remains for me is:  
  item 3: 1 unit (worth 67 to me)  
  item 4: all 6 units (6×92 = 552)  
for a total of 619, which just beats my own outside option of 617.

Even though the margin for me is narrow (only +2 over my outside offer) it seems necessary to “buy” immediate acceptance from a risk‐sensitive opponent in round‑1. 

So in round‑1 I propose the following division. I offer Player 2:  
  • 1 unit of item 1  
  • 2 units of item 2  
  • 4 units of item 3  
  • 0 units of item 4  
  • 2 units of item 5  

I would keep for myself the residual quantities (i.e. 0 of item 1, 0 of item 2, 1 unit of item 3, all 6 units of item 4, and 0 of item 5).

Thus my action is:

I’ll explain my thinking. I know that if no deal is reached each player “falls back” to their outside option, which for me is 636. (My total‐pie value is 870, so I want any deal to net me more than 636.) I also know that although I do not know Player 2’s exact values, they are drawn uniformly between 1 and 101. That means that while my values per unit are fixed – 39 for item 1, 11 for item 2, (none for item 3), 18 for item 4, and 86 for item 5 – on average Player 2 will “see” an item as worth about 51 (the midpoint of 1 and 101).  
     
My idea is to “pay” Player 2 in items whose cost to me is low (i.e. my private value is low) but that are relatively attractive to them (expected higher than mine). By contrast, I want to keep items where my value is higher than the average value for Player 2.  
     
Looking at the items:  
• Item 2: I value each unit at 11, but on average Player 2 values at about 51. Conceding the full 7 units costs me 7×11 = 77, yet it gives Player 2 roughly 7×51 = 357 expected value.  
• Item 4: I value each unit at 18 while the expected value for Player 2 is 51. Giving all 5 units costs me 5×18 = 90 and endows Player 2 with about 5×51 = 255 expected value.  
     
Together, giving up item 2 and item 4 means I “pay” a cost (in my value) of 77+90 = 167, and (in expectation) Player 2’s share is 357+255 = 612—which is very close to what we expect his outside offer (reservation) to be. This is important because if his deal‐value isn’t at least as high as his likely outside option, he won’t accept.  
     
For the remaining items:  
• Item 1: I have a relative disadvantage – I value it at 39 per unit, whereas Player 2 will likely value it at about 51 per unit. Thus, I prefer not to “give it away” too cheaply.  
• Item 5: I get 86 per unit (and the expected value to Player 2 is only about 51 per unit). So I want to keep item 5.  
     
Thus, by offering Player 2 the entirety of item 2 (7 units) and item 4 (5 units) while keeping all of item 1 (7 units) and item 5 (5 units) for myself, I get a total value of:  
  Item 1: 7×39 = 273  
  Item 5: 5×86 = 430  
  Total = 273 + 430 = 703  
which beats my outside option of 636. At the same time, Player 2 receives a package that, by average estimates, has a “value” in his eyes of about 357 + 255 = 612. (Item 3 isn’t available.)  
     
Based on this step–by–step reasoning, my initial offer as Player 1 is to give Player 2 all of item 2 and item 4 and to keep item 1 and item 5 in full. In the prescribed response format my action is:

Even though we do not know Player 2’s precise private values, we know that for each unit their value is drawn uniformly from 1 to 101 – with an expected value roughly (1+101)/2 = 51. (Note: In expectation, if Player 2 received all items, their total value would be about 6·51 + 1·51 + 4·51 + 3·51 + 2·51 = 816.) This total is comfortably above the rough reservation average (≈408) that we estimated for them.

This 777 is above our outside offer of 718.

appears reasonable for us as it gives us 777 > 718 while giving Player 1 a potential deal roughly in line with his reservation value.
